facts.text: Appellant Prabhu is the owner of agricultural land bearing Khasra Nos. 224, 215, 244, 299, 320, 506, 617 and 687 situated in village Nilakpur, Tehsil Behror, District Alwar, Rajasthan.
Appellant's father Jora executed a usufructuary mortgage of the said land in about 1936 for a period of twenty years in favour of one Ganga Din.
During continuance of the mortgage, mortgagee Ganga Din let out the land to respondents 1 to 3: Ramdey, Yadram and Nathu respectively.
Rajasthan Tenancy Act, 1955 came into force on October 15, 1955.
Appellant obtained decree for redemption on July 16, 1956, declaring mortgage and encumbrances extinguished and directing delivery of possession.
Appellant instituted suit for possession against respondents 1-3 on July 28, 1956, alleging respondents delivered possession after decree but trespassed thereafter.
Respondents denied surrendering possession and claimed right under Rajasthan Tenancy Act.
Sub-Divisional Officer, Behror tried suit, framed issues on trespass and relief, found respondents not trespassers, dismissed suit.
Appeal to Additional Commissioner, Ajmer reversed trial court, held appellant entitled to eject respondents.
Second appeal to Board of Revenue, Rajasthan succeeded for respondents, restored trial court order, held s.15 protects possession.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art.226 in Rajasthan High Court (D.B. Civil Writ No. 41 of 1959), dismissed on October 20, 1961.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondents, inducted as tenants by usufructuary mortgagee during mortgage continuance, can be ejected by appellant after redemption, in light of s.15 of Rajasthan Tenancy Act, 1955.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents are trespassers as they surrendered possession after redemption decree and re-entered wrongfully.
Tenants introduced by mortgagee during mortgage cannot claim to remain after redemption, per general rule under Transfer of Property Act and precedents Mahabir Gope and Harihar Prasad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Transfer of Property Act s.76(e); Mahabir Gope v. Harbans Narain Singh; Harihar Prasad Singh v. Mst. Munshi Nath Prasad

respondent_arguments.text: Did not surrender possession; entitled to remain under relevant provisions of Rajasthan Tenancy Act.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents satisfy definition of tenant under s.5(43), not trespassers under s.5(44); s.15 made them khatedar tenants entitled to rights and protections under Act from Oct 15, 1955; cannot be ejected except per Act (s.161); s.183 inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory provisions under Rajasthan Tenancy Act override general mortgagee-tenant rules.

court_reasoning.text: Mahabir Gope distinguished: exception where tenants acquire rights by statute during mortgage; applies here via s.15.
Harihar Prasad distinguished: turned on Bihar Tenancy Act definitions excluding mortgagee-induced tenants; no such exclusion here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision specific to Bihar Act provisions.

holdings.text: Tenants inducted by usufructuary mortgagee became khatedars under s.15 of Rajasthan Tenancy Act and protected by s.161; not ejectable post-redemption except per Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahabir Gope v. Harbans Narain Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: General rule that mortgagee cannot confer better title, but exception for statutory rights acquired by tenants during mortgage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harihar Prasad Singh v. Mst. Munshi Nath Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Tenants by mortgagee not raiyats under Bihar Tenancy Act s.5(3); specific to Bihar provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Tenancy Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined tenant and trespasser; s.15 conferred khatedar rights on tenants at commencement; s.161 barred ejectment except per Act.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mortgagee duties; general rule on leases by mortgagee ending at redemption.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction invoked in High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; respondents' possession protected as khatedars under Rajasthan Tenancy Act.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs in favour of respondent No. 1.

key_quotes.text: A mortgagee cannot, therefore, create an interest in the mortgaged property which will enure beyond the termination of his interest as mortgagee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States general rule from Mahabir Gope, later distinguished.

key_quotes.text: As soon as s.15 came into operation on October 15, 1955, the possession of the respondents... was substantially altered and they became Khatedars by virtue of the statutory provisions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of s.15.

key_quotes.text: No tenant shall be ejected from his holding otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
